text:
Hey guys, I have a question regarding replay attack protection and I hope that this is the correct channel to post this kind of question:
In section 4.3.3 of the protocol spec there’s a section on replay attack *protection*, where this will be achieved by including a generated nonce together with the user’s Ecert in a transaction. 
Yet in section 4.7 it states that “Replay attack *resistance* mechanism is not available”
Is there a difference between “protection” and “resistance”, or is the nonce-method a planned feature that is not yet added? Does that mean that there is currently no way of ensuring replay protection?
<@U21NTHK7C|wangbin767> has joined the channel
peter.froystad: i don't think this has been implemented yet
<@U21PBBLBE|serik> has joined the channel
has any one worked or knows about registering, subscribing to Chaincode Events?
<@U0KPFAZNF>:  <@U0KM61BCP> Can someone from IBM help a colleague answering client questions here ? <https://w3-connections.ibm.com/forums/html/topic?id=cf1bdfbc-8bf0-4ce9-92da-15898155c251>   Thanks
<@U21PYLBH7|mint> has joined the channel
<@U21Q40SGH|nikejain> has joined the channel
<@U21QAEEUS|samhendrickx> has joined the channel
<@U21Q268S1|hanskrommenhoek> has joined the channel
Does anyone know if a decision will be taken to choose Fabric or Sawtooth ? Or both project will keep living on parallel ?
I guess both
I heard that a decision should be taken before september
but from what I see, the 2 implementations are quite different ...
Sawtooth have a hard dependency : use Intel processor compliant
as I see they are totally different
I will say that there are some good ideas in Sawtooth that should be taken into consideration.  I liked the idea of "transaction families"  (at least that's what I recall)
So there will be 2 versions ?

attachments.fallback: [August 16th, 2016 2:24 PM] garisingh: I will say that there are some good ideas in Sawtooth that should be taken into consideration.  I liked the idea of "transaction families"  (at least that's what I recall)
attachments.text: I will say that there are some good ideas in Sawtooth that should be taken into consideration.  I liked the idea of "transaction families"  (at least that's what I recall)

text: I believe that the current goal of the Hyperledger organization is no longer (maybe never was) to have a single codebase
Is there any public document about the sawtooth / fabric differences and goals? I must say it's quite confusing ... :confused:
Thank you, I have heard so many things around me   o.O

attachments.fallback: [August 16th, 2016 2:26 PM] garisingh: I believe that the current goal of the Hyperledger organization is no longer (maybe never was) to have a single codebase
attachments.text: I believe that the current goal of the Hyperledger organization is no longer (maybe never was) to have a single codebase

text: should the two code bases be able to interact?
<@U21QNEFPF|rbrinkma> has joined the channel

<@U0XR6J961> - perhaps in an ideal world, although I am not sure it is a requirement.  It would be nice if there were modules / services which could be shared between them - which would be a level of interaction for sure
I have not really participated in the higher level protocol working group, so not sure if there is some notion of defining some standard APIs
hi
Is there a canonical list of environment variables taken by fabric peer and fabric chaincodes?
Is there any examples on User Registration and Security   / roles  or ecert ? I am trying to understand how can I can use security credentials for user validations with in the chaincode.
<@U21R1ABK8|ausi> has joined the channel
Thank you <@U20CGK1JQ>, <@U1LES78TT> and <@U0TFEHX8E> for you help. I will test it and let you know
<@U21SS2VQQ|geahaad> has joined the channel
<@U21TE1Q9E|obernin> has joined the channel
<@U0N4D2T61>: both projects will continue in parallel. hyperledger is meant to be a collection of tools
<@U0N4D2T61>: Sawtooth does not require an intel processor explicitly, one of the supported consensus mechanisms (PoET) does however
<@U21TSRV3R|patstoms> has joined the channel
there is another consensus mechanism in the sawtooth repo (quorom) that does not require an intel processor, and is similar to the ripple/stellar consensus
you could also use a traditional BFT-style consensus mechanism as well, although we have not yet released an open source version of that
Where is the blocksize parameter for hyperledger?
<@U1MNES6NR>: I agree, we need a public document highlighting the differences, we will work on getting a draft of that up that IBM can comment on
<@U1P1BT3C4>: there is no blocksize parameter for HL
to me it looked that sawtooth is mostly for intel sgx
and unless i am interested in sgx, there isn't much interesting in sawtooth
<@U0N3AJSSU>: So, a block (and its transactions) can be arbitrarily large? Is there no limit except for network constraints?
<@U1P1BT3C4>: hyperledger is focused on private deployments, some consensus mechanism used don't even contain 'blocks'
it's a parameter that can be set by those that deploy it though if it is used
<@U1JB7QCBD>: sawtooh is focused more on permisionless networks with POET
the PBFT consensus used by fabric doesn't support dynamic addition of peers, or permisionless usages
It also will be difficult for it to scale to hundreds of validators due to the consensus mechanism
yeah but permissionless is the more common thing anyway
dynamic addition of peers is something needed though
we agree :slightly_smiling_face:
so you can't add new peers to a network of fabric peers that run on pbft?
I believe that is correct
though you may want to ask in <#C0Z4NBUN6>
i was not aware of this
i will, thank you
also fabric supports execution of arbitrary chain code in docker containers
we have taken an approach where state transitions are explicitly defined
so in some sense fabric is more 'programmable' while sawtooth makes the tradeoff towards security over expressability
yeah, the arbitrary chaincode is crazy, it was trivial to write some chaincode that goes online, fetches something and does something else based on the response
i just wish go wouldn't be the only usable language

<@U0N3AJSSU> So, it’s conceivable that a single transaction could be hundreds of megabytes, and a resultant block of such transactions could grow to gigabytes? (all arbitrary) This all comes down to application logic?
<@U1P1BT3C4>:  but you don't send all the blocks to everyone
afaik
<@U1P1BT3C4>: it's a parameter that is set when you launch the network
<@U0N3AJSSU>: Yes, you can set the number of transactions per block. But there doesn’t seem to be a limit on the size of a single transaction?
well fabric doesn't use blocks as far as i know
but yes, for example the deploy transaction on fabric allows you to push a smart contract to the network which could be arbitrarily large i believe
but with both you could enforce a max transaction size or max block size
when i say both I mean sawtooth and fabric
<@U0N3AJSSU>: Thanks.
no problem
<@U21TTHA7Q|frozent> has joined the channel
Cool ! Thanks :slightly_smiling_face:

when i am issuing he command  "/project/sawtooth-validator
$ ./bin/txnvalidator -v --http 8800 --config /project/sawtooth-docs/source/tutorial/txnvalidator.js “  from the Sawtooth tutorial <http://intelledger.github.io/tutorial.html#building-sawtooth-core)> it gives me a error stating -http 8800 command is not found. When remove the “http” parameter it works fine, is there a typo there?

<@U0YQQRNU8>: is the tutorial config file updated or is the guidance to use the one in etc?

I saw several things were removed from rest_api.json (e.g. port 5000 -> 7050, and deploy function schema was removed)
It seemed the code on gerrit, REST API is now going to be deprecated? is that correct?
So, which direction should I go for, node.js SDK, or direct grpc?
<@U2231CUH3|inatatsu> has joined the channel
<@U223FR55X|libin.nj> has joined the channel

Hey all,  
I have a doubt.  
Does anyone know how the images for peer and memberservices are built in docker-hub?
They might be using fabric code stored somewhere to build these images, right?
I guess the images are uploaded from somewhere. Docker-hub works that way
Yeah, but what is that "somewhere”? That is my doubt.
I guess it is the CI - Jenkins

Actually, the problem is that I am working with docker images for peer and memberservices as published by docker-hub. 
Now, If I change something in my local fabric code, how to reflect that change in the containers for peer and memberservices because peer and member services are still using those images published by docker-hub.
Is there any way by which I could reflect my changes in fabric code to the containers for peer and services?
the images can be built locally. I have never tried using the ones from docker hub. make images builds all the images locally. make peer-image compiles peer image and the ones needed for that

In the documentation for “outside of vagrant” setup, they have pulled images for both the things from docker-hub and I was following that documentation.
By the way, When I run make peer-image, I get the following error

Step 2 : ADD gopath.tar.bz2 $GOPATH/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric
Error processing tar file(bzip2 data invalid: bad magic value in continuation file): 
make: *** [build/image/src/.dummy] Error 1
<@U1AU8DRQR>: Do u know how to eliminate this error?
so are you running it outside of vagrant?
yup.
and the docs say that you have to download those images from docker-hub, right?
Yeah, they are using that way only.
are you on mac?
Yes.
ah cool
I think <@U0R7Q5C30> had a similar problem
Error processing tar file(bzip2 data invalid: bad magic value in continuation file): <- this is caused by - not 100% sure but - Mac specific tar implementation
one should install gnu tar maybe
I will ping u again if i have some other issue.@hgabor
okay
